reference.title: Backing up and restoring applications
reference.shortdesc: In some situations, you might want to back up configuration information and data from an application and then later restore that instance. You might back up on a regular schedule to provide a historical archive; or infrequently, such as when you want to move data from one instance to another or perhaps duplicate an instance for testing or failover purposes.

section.p: The backup process saves the state of all services and data to a .tgz file that you can restore on that cluster or duplicate on a similar cluster. The state of the system at the time of the backup is stored; however, specific snapshots are not backed up. As a best practice, take periodic backups.

You can resume a restore from a backup if an outage occurs during the restore. preserves complete data on your system. For example, you ran a restore and two of the six backed up snapshots were restored. Those two snapshots are saved on the system, and are not downloaded again from the backup file when you resume the restore.

When a backup is running, you can start and restart services. Because snapshots are loaded to disk, you are not required to stop services during a restore while the file is loaded. Though the restore will not complete successfully, the snapshot and images are available for you to manually rollback each application.

A full backup is not always necessary; for example, when you need a checkpoint prior to installing software. In these cases, you can perform a snapshot of the system. If you need to revert back to a snapshot, use the rollback feature (before which you will need to stop services that are used in the particular snapshot image). For more information, see .Any backups that you took using 1.0.x cannot be restored in 1.1.x or later versions.If you manually deleted the default pool, you cannot restore from a backup. The default pool is created on startup and is required.
